concepts.vibration: Rapid back-and-forth movement of an object
concepts.frequency: Number of vibrations per second, measured in Hertz (Hz)
concepts.ratios: The ratio between two frequencies, not their arithmetic difference
concepts.cents: 1/100th of a semitone. 1200 cents = 1 octave. Measures pitch the way humans hear it.
concepts.fundamental: The lowest frequency of vibration, the pitch you consciously hear
concepts.overtones: Frequencies above the fundamental that occur naturally when a string vibrates
concepts.harmonicSeries: The series of frequencies produced by a vibrating object: f, 2f, 3f, 4f...
concepts.consonance: A pleasant, stable sound when two or more notes are played together
concepts.dissonance: A tense, unstable sound that creates a sense of wanting to resolve
concepts.interval: The distance in pitch between two notes, measured in semitones (half steps)
concepts.scale: A set of notes (usually 7) selected from the 12 chromatic notes, ordered by pitch
concepts.chord: Three or more notes sounded simultaneously
concepts.voicing: A specific arrangement of a chord's notes across the strings of an instrument
concepts.key: A scale plus its tonic (home chord). Defines which notes and chords 'belong' together.
concepts.tonic: The first degree of a scale, the chord that feels like 'home'
concepts.circleOfFifths: A diagram arranging all 12 keys by the number of sharps/flats in their key signature
concepts.diatonic: Chords built only from the notes of the current scale
concepts.chordProgression: A sequence of chords played in order, creating harmonic movement
concepts.harmonicFunction: The role a chord plays in a key: tonic (home), dominant (tension), or subdominant (departure)
concepts.cadence: A chord movement from dominant to tonic that creates a strong sense of resolution
